prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not helping a student?
I teach first grade in a very rural, low-economic area.  The average household is right at or below the poverty line; the only exceptions are the professionals in our community.  

Every year I offer to tutor my students who are below level in reading and/or math.  I do this free of charge (in my district, charging money for tutoring your own students is a conflict of interest.).  The tutoring sessions last forty five minutes and start immediately after school.  School lets out at 2:40, we start our lesson @ 2:50.  I provide a snack for the students since lunch time was at 11:00 and kids don’t focus well when they are hungry.  I pay for the snacks myself.  

Anyway, I had a parent from another school contact me out of the blue.  I was tutoring her best friend’s daughter (one of my kiddos, remember) and she wanted to know if I’d also tutor her son.  She told me his reading level, which was abysmal, and I have a really hard time saying no to a child in need.  I told her the tutoring times and said that if she could get the child there in time I would help.  

Turns out, the child attends school in a different county approximately an hour’s drive away.  The school also dismisses thirty minutes later than we do.  Obviously Mom can’t get the student to me in time.  So she asks if I would wait and tutor her son separately.

This means the child would arrive around 4:15.  I get to work at 6:30 and by 4:15 I am simply out of energy.  Besides, I have to help my own son with his school work and that’s always a hassle.  It takes me 40 minutes to drive home, which would mean I’d get home about 5:45, depending on traffic.  

The going rate for reading tutors in this area is $30 bucks per hour.  I wanted compensation for my time, so I told her the cost would be $25 per session.  

She completely flipped out.  Called me all sorts of horrible names and made some very uncouth remarks about my teaching ability.  The one that hurt the most was that I didn’t care about the kids, I’m just in it for the money, etc.  She told me I was a disgrace to teaching and incredibly selfish, and that this kind of shit was why everyone hates public school teachers.

Her words are constantly replaying in my head.  I don’t think I am an asshole for asking for compensation, but am I the asshole for not tutoring her student?
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The teacher is asking if they're the asshole for not helping another student from a different school. So, the situation is that they already tutor their own students for free after school, providing snacks and doing it all themselves. Then a parent from another school asks if they can tutor their son too, but he's in a different county and school. The teacher offers to do it for $25 per session, but the parent gets really angry and calls them names.

First, I need to consider the teacher's circumstances. They're already doing free tutoring for their own students, which is commendable. They're in a low-economic area, so the parent might be struggling financially, but the teacher is also giving up their own time. The teacher works until 2:40, starts tutoring at 2:50, which is right after school. If they tutor another student later, the timing is an issue because they have their own son's homework to help with and the drive home. So the teacher's energy and time are limited.

The parent's request is for a student in a different school, which might not even be under the teacher's school district. The teacher isn't obligated to tutor that student. They tried to accommodate by offering a later session but needed compensation because it's outside their normal schedule and personal time. The parent then accuses the teacher of not caring about kids and being greedy. 

The key points here are the teacher's right to set boundaries, the fact that they already do a lot for free, the logistical challenges, and the parent's inappropriate reaction. The teacher isn't required to tutor another student's child, especially outside their school. Charging a fair rate for personal time is reasonable. The parent's hostile response seems unwarranted. So the teacher isn't in the wrong here. They did offer help but had valid reasons for not proceeding. The parent's accusation of selfishness doesn't hold up considering the teacher's existing commitments and the parent's own circumstances. Therefore, the answer should be B.
